Graphic abstract The preparation, structure–performance relationship of various of PtCu–based multimetallic alloys with excellent performance for the MOR and ORR applied in energy conversion systems. Proton exchange membrane fuel cell and direct methanol fuel cells have gained more attention due to high–energy density, remarkable conversion efficiency, and low emission. However, their widely practical application was hindered by the high usage, limited sources, and high price of Pt catalysts. To achieve more cost–effective catalytic systems, PtCu–based multi–metallic nanoparticles are highly efficient for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and methanol oxidation reaction (MOR). The incorporation of non–noble Cu metal can alter the properties of hybrids by forming new facets, planes, edges to promote the cleavage or formation of chemical bonds in catalytic reaction. This is a rapid growing area with numerous contributions from the interdisciplinary areas of nanocatalysis. This paper has summarized the recent progress in the past two years, in synthesizing PtCu–based alloys with various composition and morphologies, and critically discussed the effect of the catalyst preparation method, metal precursor, surfactant, reductant and heating temperature on nanostructure and electronic configuration. The important role of the composition, size, and morphology of PtCu bimetallic catalysts for electro oxidation reactions has been further established for structure–dependency studies. The challenges and perspectives of nanocatalysts for ORR and MOR discussed in this work is to provide further insights into rational design for cost–effective materials for energy. Fuel cells is a device that converted the chemical energy in the feedstocks to electric energy through electrochemical reactions with high efficiency and zero emissions. However, the performance of fuel cells is still limited by the sluggish kinetics of the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) at the cathode for proton exchange membrane fuel cell (PEMFC) [2,3]. Furthermore, the methanol oxidation reaction (MOR) at the anode for direct methanol fuel cell (DMFC) with high efficiency is still challenging [4,5]. Pt–based catalysts are reported highly active in various energy conversion processes [6–9]. However, high cost and scarcity of noble Pt metal have hindered the application of Pt–based catalysts. Hence, it is highly desirable to decrease the usage of Pt by improving the efficiency of Pt–based nanomaterials or by developing Pt–based multi–metallic catalyst with non–noble promoters, such as Co, Ni, Mn, Fe and Cu [10–12]. It is important to mention that, Pt catalysts incorporated with non-noble metal materials are only one class of promising candidates for fuel cell applications. Other candidates have already been proven to be remarkable for applications at commercial scales. For example, PtRu- and PtPd- based alloys have been widely used in the DMFCs due to the excellent catalytic performances [13–16]. However, the noble Ru and Pd metal are highly expensive, which would not be discussed in this work. PtCu–based metallic catalysts have been widely applied in fuel cells with good performance, for ORR [17–20], MOR [4,5,21–31], ethanol oxidation reaction (EOR) [32–36], ethylene glycol oxidation reaction [37–40], and formic acid oxidation reaction (FOR) [41–44]. Comparing to other metals, Cu crystals display similar lattice parameters with Pt structures, enabling facile formation of well–defined alloyed structures with predictable electronic configuration [43]. Cu has the potential to replace the Pt group metals due to the special structural traits. The incorporation of Cu metal can alter the surface electronic configuration with a possible lowering of the d band center for Pt [45]. The surface Pt in the alloy structures possess lower binding energies for O* and OH* species [46]. The performance of PtCu alloy for ORR can be significantly enhanced owing to such tunable adsorption properties for intermediate species [37]. Furthermore, the alloyed nanostructures also induce an enhancement of surface roughness and modified Pt–Pt atomic distance, thus boost the catalytic performances significantly [47,48]. Even through the dissolution of Cu from the de–alloyed catalyst during the operation of fuel cells may poison the membrane and ionomer by binding the SO3 – group, and degrade the anode reaction efficiency [49], stable PtCu–based nano–alloy materials with negligible Cu dissolution displayed both technological and economic advantages to substitute commercial Pt/C catalytic materials in the future. Hence, it is highly desired to improve the catalytic activity and stability of the PtCu catalyst. The strong dependence of the intrinsic activity and stability on the structure of the PtCu–base alloy nanoparticles motivated extensive research efforts on investigating composition– and shape–controlled synthesis methods [50,51]. PtCu–Based nanoparticles display strong synergism compared with commercial Pt–based catalysts ascribing to strong Pt–Cu electronic coupling and the highly available surface active sites in the nanostructures [52]. There is a large difference on redox potentials of Pt and Cu salt precursors, making it difficult to achieve simultaneous reduction. Hence, initially Pt or Cu nanocrystals are prepared by under–potential deposition (UPD) method and PtCu alloy are obtained by galvanic replacement [53,54]. A variety of PtCu–based alloys with diverse morphological features were prepared by various protocols, including seeded growth, galvanic replacement, UPD, chemical etching, sacrificial template, and nanoassemblies [55–57]. By varying the preparation methods, numerous PtCu–based alloy with different structures (Fig. 1 ) were successfully synthesized, e.g., tripod/tetragonal nanostructure [58–60], hexagonal nanoframe [61,62], octahedral nanoframe [63–66], decahedral nanoframe [67], dodecahedral nanoframe [68,69], dendrites [70,71], nanowires [72–74], nanocube [75–78], nanosphere [79–84] and core–shell [44,85] structures. One can alter the surface energies by controlling the progress and operating conditions, e.g., capping agents, seeds structures, solvent, surfactant, metal precursor, reductant, temperature and the time for hydrothermal treatment to control the reaction kinetics and growing rate in a shape–controlled synthesis. Methanol tolerance is another critical factor to be considered for catalyst durability, with potential leaking of methanol to the cathode during the operation [86–91]. MOR at cathode may cause a drop of the cathodic current, surface poisoning of the catalyst owing to the formation of by–product, thus inducing significant drop in fuel cell power efficiency [92]. Levin et al. prepared a Cu impregnated Pt catalyst by electrodeposition on a poly[Cu(salen)] template (31 nm) and observed a higher activity and methanol tolerance comparing to the commercial Pt/C catalyst [92]. The smaller particle size and more inhomogeneous surface are viewed as the main reason of higher methanol tolerance [92]. The effect of particle size is consistent with the conclusion observed by Maillard’s group [90] and Yang’s group [93]. Furthermore, it was reported that the chemisorption of methanol for MOR required at least three adjacent Pt active sites in certain crystallographic arrangement [88,89,91]. However, the chemisorption of oxygen for ORR only required two adjacent Pt active sites. Hence, the incorporation of methanol–tolerance Cu can decrease the density of Pt active sites and increased the methanol tolerance of Pt–based catalysts. Wang et al. reported that PtCuBiMn catalysts have almost no degradation or current density loss during tests [94]. They proposed that the presence of Bi distorted the adjacent three Pt sites for methanol chemisorption, thus suppressed the methanol oxidation. Manthiram et al. synthesized Pt@PdCu5 with core–shell structure using PdCu5 as core by polyol reduction and galvanic displacement method [95]. They study the effect of Pt content and coverage to the activity and methanol tolerance. The catalyst with high Pt coverage displayed low Cu dissolution, but methanol tolerance is also not high comparing to the catalyst with less Pt content [95]. The presence of Pd and Cu improved the methanol tolerance compared to the Pt/C catalyst. Hence, it is concluded that the presence of non–Pt metal in multimetallic catalyst, especially methanol tolerant Cu, can not only increase the catalytic performance, but also improve the methanol tolerance. The research focus on PtCu–based catalysts for energy conversion has seen a remarkable growth spurt over the past two year. The number of the reference most relevant to this topic published in 2020 is likely closed to the sum of 2017 to 2019 (Fig. 2 ). The rapid development of nanotechnology and material science significantly promoted the development of the characterization techniques of Pt–based bimetallic nanostructures. Furthermore, it was found that the research before 2020 is mainly focus on the studying the structure of the PtCu nanocrystals with larger size [96–99]. However, during 2020, more and more groups focus on preparing multi–metallic PtCu–based catalyst with ultrafine nanocrystals and ultra–low Pt content, e.g. PtCuAu [100–106], PtCuNi [45,107–112], PtCuPd [113–119], PtCuCo [120], PtCuSn [36], PtCuRu [121,122], PtCuRh [123], PtCuFe [4], PtCuMn [124], PtCuBi [30], and PtCuTi [2,125,126]. Therefore, it is highly necessary to revise and summarize the most recent achievement on PtCu–based catalysts for fuel cells promptly, in terms of preparation, characterization, catalytic activity, and the stability. In this review article, various PtCu bimetallic catalysts with distinct structures (Fig. 2) and morphologies will be critically revised for finding the relationship between the synthesis method, structural characterization, stability, and relevant performance in energy conversion reactions, especially ORR and MOR. 2 Nanocrystal structure Trigonal PtCu structures exhibited superior catalytic performances comparing to the commercial Pt/C catalyst for the electrooxidation reactions [59]. The porous and interconnected structure of the untrathin nanoframes in the trigonal bipyramidal provided larger surface area and exposed more PtCu (111) surface planes, which give them enhanced dispersion and more active sites [127]. The surface permeability of nanoframes improved accessibility of ions, atoms, and molecules compared to conventional nanocrystals, thus accelerated mass diffusion during heterogeneous reactions [18]. PtCu–based alloy with 3D interconnected trigonal bipyramidal structure can be prepared by heating the mixture of potassium iodide (KI), ethylene glycol (EG), polyvinyl chloroplatinic acid (H2PtCl6·6H2O), pyrrolidone (PVP) and copper chloride dehydrate (CuCl2·2H2O) for 90 min at 140 °C [18]. As the time prolonged, truncated cubes formed and turned to trigonal bipyramidal structure in a progressive fashion. Even further treatment time cause agglomeration of particles, which destroyed the porous structures and reduced overall active surface area. X–ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) studies confirmed the existence of Pt oxides and the absence of Cu2+ in the alloy. As it is well known, the difference in the redox potential of Pt and Cu is significant. Therefore, it is difficult to form alloy in the absence of template agents. KI can induce the generation of Pt complexes, e.g. PtI6 2– and PtCl6 2–, to slow the reduction rate of Pt precursors. The redox potential of Pt4+/Pt and Cu2+/Cu can therefore be tuned and controlled. Consequently, Pt and Cu precursors will be reduced simultaneously to obtain PtCu alloy [59,60]. PVP, often used as capping agent and soft template, can prevent the particles from agglomeration. The catalyst was brush coated on the gas diffusion layer (1 mgPt/cm2) as the air cathode of a zinc–air battery and tested for the performance of ORR in 0.1 M KOH solution. Trigonal PtCu alloys supported on graphene oxide displayed 2–fold higher specific activity (SA) for ORR compared to the Pt/C catalysts (40%, Table 1 , #1). The presence of Cu in the alloy makes Pt more electron rich and facilitate the electron transfer to oxygen in the ORR. Furthermore, the porous structure and interconnected network have more (111) planes and active sites in the alloy [128]. The rotating disc electrode system was applied for calculating the number of electrons involved in reduction steps. The results indicated a 4–electron mechanism of the reduction process as only water rather than H2O2 was observed as by–product. The stability test indicated there is only 7 mV negative shift of E1/2 value which is far less than the Pt/C (37 mV) after 1000 cycles. The alloy structure and graphene provided better support and suffered from less corrosion compared to the carbon supported Pt [128]. Xu’s group prepared PtCu alloy with hierarchical concave triangular dendrites (HCLT) or hierarchical trigonal bipyramid nanoframes (HTBNF) structure by one–pot hydrothermal method using DL–carnitine, KI, PVP, CuCl2, and H2PtCl6 (Fig. 3 a–d) [59]. By changing KI amounts from 20 to 140 mg, the catalyst varied from HTBNF to HCLT structures slowly. In HCLT structure, the number of layers can be tuned by changing the DL–carnitine concentration, reducing Pt complexes to generate Pt nanoparticles. In the absence of H2PtCl6 or CuCl2, only spherical nanoparticles formed. Studies on formation mechanism showed that, PtCu alloy formed through the UPD of Cu atoms on the surface of Pt followed by the galvanic replacement reaction with Pt4+. The formation of PtCu nanoparticles occurred by directionally overgrowth, rather than particle aggregation. PtCu HCLT showed relatively higher activity and stability than PtCu HTBNF and commercial Pt/C for FOR applications ascribing to the interconnected rich active edge dendritic structures (Table 1, #2). PtCuNi eb–NFs with external branch nanoframes (branch diameter 8 nm) was synthesized by one–pot reduction approach in the presence of ethylene glycol, NaI, PVP and glycine (Gly) [110]. In this method, alcohol and Gly/NaI are the main factors in tuning the internal structure and external architecture, respectively. As the Gly amount decreased, or the NaI amount increased, the concave nanocube (PtCuNi ec–NFs, Fig. 3e) evolved to multihierarchical branches (PtCuNi eb–NFs, Fig. 3f) and hexpods (PtCuNi eh–NFs, Fig. 3g). The catalyst was dispersed on a Al2O3–polished glass carbon electrode before testing on an electrochemical analyzer in the presence of N2 saturated 0.5 M H2SO4 and 2 M CH3OH. PtCuNi eb–NFs showed higher activity for MOR then PtCuNi ec/eh–NFs due to the higher defect density on the special geometry. The SA of PtCuNi eb–NFs is 10.7 times higher than the commercial Pt/C for MOR (Table 1, #3), ascribing to higher defects density with high anti–CO–poisoning stability. High external surface area, abundant high–index facets, subtle lattice distortion and more vacancy are the main reason of forming these unsaturated defects which are recognized as the major active sites for MOR with higher adsorption ability for OH group [110]. Furthermore, the kinetic study indicated that this is a diffusion–controlled process. PtCuNi eb–NFs has enhanced methanol diffusion rates than other catalysts [110]. The faster diffusion rates can make it less prone to re–adsorb CO species, thus improve the anti–CO–poisoning stability. On the other hand, Cu species promoted the formation of oxygenated OH species which was further oxidized and thus get rid of the CO intermediates from the Pt active sites [129,130]. In another study, PtCu HTBNFs were also synthesized and the particle size was varied from 110 to 250 nm by tuning the amount of KI and the Pt/Cu feeding ratio. In the absence of Cu2+, nanoflowers (25 nm, Fig. 3h) with disordered branches formed rather than HTBNFs [60]. The presence of Cu2+ led to the growth of seeds to form a stacking faults structure. Hence, the Pt/Cu ratio has significant effect to the nucleation and growth kinetics. The structure of the PtCu alloy varied with reaction time, which indicated that the PtCu bimetallic formed by co–deposition of Pt0 and Cu0. Both PtCu HTBNFs displayed higher catalytic activity for FOR than the commercial Pt/C due to the synergistic effect of PtCu and the unique hierarchical structures. PtCu alloy with 3D hierarchical tetragonal and dendritic structures (HTD) were prepared by a facile template–free hydrothermal method. Scanning Electron Microscopic (SEM) and Transmission Electron Microscopic (TEM) images displayed uniform tetragonal structures with edges (length of 200 nm) and large amounts of interconnected arms (35 nm, Fig. 3i) [58]. The PtCu HTD formed due to metal etching by I2 and the galvanic replacement between Pt4+ and Cu. NaI as etching and shape directing agent controlled the shape, size, and number of branches. PVP played a role of reductant and stabilizer. Hence, in the absence of NaI and PVP, only small aggregated particles formed without any dendritic structure. PtCu HTD exhibited superior electrocatalytic activity and stability for MOR compared to the commercial Pt/C due to the interconnected arms and exposed surfaces with sufficient absorption active sites (Table 1, #4). Du’s group reported a versatile shape–controlled synthesis approach of PtCu tripods (TPRs) [131]. The structure of the PtCu alloy varied from concave nanocubes (CNCs) to excavated nanocubes (ENCs), to 2D tripods with small branches (TPRs, Fig. 3j) via increasing the amount of Gly, which acted as reducing agent. In the absence of KI, only some irregular nanomaterials formed. Hence, KI played an important role for the successful preparation of PtCu alloy. The structure of the alloy has significant effect to the catalytic performance. Catalyst was mixed with Nafion and isopropanol (IPA) solution, then was dispersed on glass carbon electrode, and tested in the N2–saturated 1 M KOH and 1 M CH3OH solution in a CHI instrument. The SA of PtCu CNCs for MOR is 1.2–, 1.4–, and 8.2–times of those of PtCu TRPs, PtCu ENCs, and Pt/C, respectively, owing to the highly exposed high–index facets and active surface areas (Table 1, #5). The stability test showed that the activity decrease of PtCu CNCs is 46.3% and Pt/C is 76.7% after 1000 cycle CV measurements. 3 Hexagonal nanostructure Hexagonal nanocubes was as basic unit of the rhombic dodecahedron structure [132,133]. PtCu alloys with hexagonal nanoframe or hexapod structure displayed superior electrocatalytic activity than the commercial Pt/C catalyst for the ORR and MOR reactions [99,134]. The good catalytic ability was ascribing to the 3D open structure with larger surface area, highly accessible active sites, and the abundant tips with negative charges on the ultrathin pods [135]. Furthermore, the incorporation of Cu modified the electronic properties and generated beneficial synergistic effects [136,137]. Alloyed PtCu3 hexapods and hollow nanoframes were synthesized by co–reduction of Cu and Pt salts by Cl– ion–guided UPD and galvanic replacement at different temperatures in the presence of N,N–dimethylformamide (DMF) and oleylamine (OAm) as reductants [61]. PtCu3 hexapods were obtained at 220 °C due to the higher reduction rate and faster overgrowth (Fig. 4 a). At 190 °C, Pt precursor and PtCu3 alloy undergo galvanic replacement and overgrowth resulted in PtCu3 hollow nanoframes with a size of 20 nm as observed from the TEM images (Fig. 4b). The growth mechanism study showed that polyhedral nanocrystals with exposed basic facets were formed at the beginning. After 20 min, these polyhedral nanocrystals have grown into rhombic dodecahedral shapes with the exposed (220) facets. Eventually, the rhombic dodecahedral shape was etched by galvanic replacement and the hollow nanoframes was obtained. The as–prepared catalyst was mixed with DI water, Nafion, and IPA with a ratio of 8/0.05/2, pained on a rotating disk electrode (RDE) and tested in an Ar–saturated 0.5 M CH3OH/0.5 M H2SO4 solution with a CHI760E workstation. The alloyed PtCu3 hexapods and hollow nanoframes displayed higher activity towards MOR, which are 13.5 and 24.2 times higher than that of the commercial Pt/C, respectively (Table 1, #6). The long–term current–time test indicated PtCu3 nanoframes showed higher current density through 2000 s than the Pt/C catalyst, indicating a better stability and improved anti–CO–poisoning ability. The improvement of the activity and stability were due to the formation of hollow structure, high–index facets, surface defects and the synergistic effect of Pt and Cu. 3D ultrathin PtCu hexapods (3.6 nm in diameter, 15.3 nm in length) with abundant tips and large surface area were reported by Shen’s group as displayed in the TEM and High–Resolution Transmission Electron Microscope (HRTEM) images (Fig. 4c,d) [138]. Cu promoted the formation of ultrathin PtCu hexapods due to the less negative reduction potential of PtCl6 2–/Pt0 than that of the Cu2+/Cu0. OAm and NaI acted as the reductant and the structure–directing agent, respectively. The feeding amount of NaI controlled the diameter and length of the hexapods. The growing mechanism study indicated that polyhedral nanocrystals with (111) and (100) facets formed at the first stage. Then more and more atoms were deposited on the (100) facets selectively to make the pods grow longer to obtain a hexapod structure. The catalyst was mixed with ethanol and Nafion solution, dispersed on a glass carbon RDE, and tested in N2–saturated 0.5 M H2SO4 and 1 M CH3OH solution. The catalytic activity of the as–prepared ultrathin PtCu hexapods towards MOR is 3.1 and 1.8 times higher compared to those of commercial Pt/C and PtCu nanodendrites (Table 1, #7). The excellent performance is ascribing to their open structure with largely available surface area and abundant tips with negative charges. Feng’s group synthesized 3D PtCu alloyed hollow hexagonal nanoframes (PtCu HHNFs) with side length around 5.6 nm by one step co–reduction approach using CTAC, ethanolamine, Cl−/O2, and OAm as structure directing, reducing, oxidation etching, and co–reducing agents, respectively (Fig. 4e) [139]. PtCu HHNFs presented boosted SA and durability compared with industrial Pt/C catalysts in alkaline solutions for the ORR. A facile hot–injection process was reported for synthesizing concave PtCu3 nanocubes with high index facets of (720), (520), and (320) [134]. CTAB and trinoctylphospine oxide (TOPO) facilitate the galvanic replacement reaction of Pt on the (100) facets and the formation of uniform concave nanocube structure, respectively (Fig. 4f). The SA of PtCu3 concave nanocube is 4.4 times higher than the commercial Pt/C for MOR, ascribing to the concave structure and synergistic electronic effect. Pt5PdCu5 alloy hexapods with an average size of 31.8 nm were synthesized by one pot reduction of metal precursors in the mixture of OAm, DMF and TOPO [117]. In this case, truncated octahedral crystals formed at the first stage as seeds. Then pods formed by overgrow on the desired facets of the octahedral seeds. The catalyst was mixed DI water, IPA and Nafion solution, dispersed on the RDE, and tested in 0.5 M CH3OH and Ar–purged 0.5 M H2SO4 and solution. The as prepared catalysts exhibited 19.4 times higher SA than that of commercial Pt/C (Table 1, #8). The ligand effect of Pd, Cu and Pt and the bifunctional mechanism are the main factors for the good catalytic performance. TEM, Scanning Transmission Electron Microscope (STEM) and Energy Dispersive X–ray Spectroscopy (EDX) mapping showed hexapod single crystal with Pd–rich interior and well dispersed Pt and Cu on the hexapod (Fig. 4g–i). The Pd–rich core formation indicated that Cu is alloyed with Pd before Pt due to the higher redox potential of Pd2+/Pd. Pt5PdCu5 has higher activity than Pt2PdCu4, indicating the ratio of Cu, Pt and Pd has significant effect to the catalytic performance. Long–term current–time measurement results showed a highly steady current density of Pt5PdCu5 hexapods during the entire test (1000 s), which is more stable than Pt/C due to the weaker CO adsorption and thus higher anti–CO–poisoning ability. 4 Octahedral nanostructure PtCu octahedral alloy can be prepared by one–pot approach using glucose as structure directing agent [64]. By altering the ratio of Pt(acac)2 to Cu(acac)2, the morphology of the PtCu alloy can be changed (Fig. 5 a). Without adding any Cu(acac)2, the uniform nanocubes with a size of 3.2 nm formed. X–Ray Diffraction (XRD) patents of the Pt34.5Cu65.5 alloy can be indexed to (111), (200), (220) and (311) diffractions of a face–centered cubic (fcc) structure. The SA of the octahedral Pt34.5Cu65.5 is 4.7 times higher than that on commercial PtB for MOR and 7.7 times higher than PtB for ORR. Glucose–directed synthesis of Pt31Cu69 alloy with nanowire structure were carried out by and one–step co–reduction method under room temperature in the absence of surfactant [40]. The glucose acted as stabilizing and growth–directing agent. The as prepared Pt31Cu69 NWs exhibited higher durability and activity towards ethylene glycol oxidation, which is 1.8 times higher than that of commercial Pt/C ascribing to the unique 3D network structure and the synergetic effects. Alloyed PtCu octahedral nanocrystals with minor truncation of the corners (10 nm in edge length, Fig. 5b) was synthesized by a one–pot approach using I−, rather than large surfactants, as shape–directing agent to form (111) facets [140]. In comparison with organic large surfactants (CTAB, CTAC or OAm), the adsorbed I− ions are easier to be get rid of by water/ethanol washing, to emerge free surface area. In the absence of I−, only cuboctahedral or irregular particles formed. However, excessive NaI will ruin the octahedral shape. The catalyst was mixed with DI water/IPA (4:1) and Nafion (5 wt%), dispersed on a glass carbon RDE, and then tested in the solution of O2–saturated 0.1 M HClO4 solution at 30 °C. The SA of the PtCu/C octahedra is 21.3 times higher than that of commercial Pt/C catalyst (Table 1, #9). They also found that the durability of PtCu/C can be improved significantly by incorporating trace Au on the surface gap and defect sites to restrain the dissolution/diffusion of Pt atoms. The accelerated durability test (ADT) indicated that the half–wave potential of PtCu/C only has 14 mV negative shifts after 10,000 potential cycles, which is less than 23 mV of Pt/C. There is 32% loss of mass activity (MA) which is less than the 52% loss of Pt/C. The authors believe that larger size of PtCu nanocrystal (10 nm) might be the main reason of higher stability. Truncated octahedral PtCu nanocrystals with a uniform size (~5 nm) were prepared using DMF as solvent [141]. Octahedral Pt4Cu nanocrystalls were prepared by reducing Cu(acac)2 and Pt(acac)2 in the presence of DMF, CTAC and n–butylamine through a solvothermal method [65]. The PtCu3 alloy is composed of well–defined octahedral nanocrystals with eight (111) facets and an average edge length of 30 nm (Fig. 5c). By adding more n–butylamine, more proportion of Cu (up to 75%) can be incorporated in the Pt4Cu alloy. Every Pt atom is able to bind as much as 12 Cu atoms by the synergistic effect in the alloyed Pt4Cu crystal. As the reaction time increased to 12 h, reduction of the excessive Pt precursors occurred and Pt nanocrystals formed as a by–product when the reaction run out of Cu precursors. Hence, it is apparently faster and easier to form PtCu3 alloy than pure Pt phase. The Pt4Cu crystals self–assembled into metal–frameworks and displayed high MA, which is 5.1 times higher comparing to the commercial Pt/C catalyst towards the ORR (Table 1, #10). The MA of Pt4Cu is still higher than the Pt/C after 8000 cycles during the ADT. It was noticed that the basic composition of the Pt4Cu catalyst has negligible difference after 8000 cycles. The synthesis of Alloyed PtCu3 octahedra via UPD–like process was reported [142]. PtCu3 showed superior catalytic performance and anti–poisoning ability than Pt1Cu1 alloys. The electro–catalytic activity of the PtCu alloy improved as the Cu content increased. PtNiCu based multimetallic catalysts are reported highly active for ORR and MOR reaction [45,107–111]. A trimetallic octahedral PtNiCu alloy nanocrystalls (PtNiCu ROHNC, Fig. 5d) was obtained via a facile solvothermal approach using PVP as a reductant and stabilizing agent in this process [42]. In the absence of PVP, only a few heavily aggregated irregular particles formed. By increasing the Gly amount, the structures varied from crosses to spherical dendrites. The time sequential evolution results indicated that Cu and Ni atoms were generated from Cu2+ and Ni2+ reduction at the first place, and Pt catalyzed galvanic replacement then occurs at the interface. The PtNiCu ROHNC had more active sites, thus displayed a higher SA, which is 5.5 times of that of the commercial Pt/C catalyst for MOR (Table 1, #11) in the electrolyte containing 2 M CH3OH and N2–saturated 0.5 M H2SO4. The long–term current–time measurement was tested for 1000 s and indicated that PtNiCu ROHNC has higher stability than PtB and Pt/C. In another work, alloyed PtPdCu concave nanooctahedra (PtPdCu ACNOs) were obtained by a two–step approach from PtCu nanodendrites [143]. The as prepared PtPdCu ACNOs displayed much higher catalytic performance comparing to the parent PtCu nanodendrites and the commercial Pt/C towards the MOR. PtCu alloy nanocrystalls with concave octahedra (COH), yolk–shell (YSH), porous octahedra (POH), and nanoflower (NOF) structures were obtained by varying the amount of precursors and Gly in aqueous phase (Fig. 5e) [144]. The morphology of the PtCu bimetallic nanocrystalls can be modified by varying the amounts of H2PtCl6 and Gly to alter the sequential reduction kinetics. A low concentration of Gly can slow down the reduction rate of Cu2+ ions and promote the reduction rate of Pt4+ ions simultaneously. It is preferred to maintain low reduction rate to obtain octahedral PtCu alloy nanocrystals. Otherwise, PtCu nanocrystals with irregular morphologies were obtained. These catalysts were mixed with ethanol and water and dropped onto Al2O3–polished glassy carbon electrode. The electrode was then covered with 0.05 wt% Nafion in ethanol. A solution of 2 M CH3OH and N2–saturated 0.5 M H2SO4 was used as electrolyte. The COH (3.8 mA/cm2) and NOF (2.8 mA/cm2) PtCu with more intragranular dislocations and lumps showed higher activity than that of POH (1.7 mA/cm2) and YSH (2.2 mA/cm2) PtCu and the commercial Pt/C (0.48 mA/cm2) catalyst for MOR (Table 1, #12). Furthermore, COH PtCu showed larger down–shift in the CO–stripping experiment indicating a higher CO tolerance than Pt/C. The enhanced catalytic activity and durability is ascribing to the excellent morphologies with more atomic steps and edges, thus, more active sites. A solvothermal approach to synthesize core–shell concave Cu@CuPt octahedron with high–index surfaces of (312) and (413) and atomic steps was presented [22]. The STEM image of the PtCu alloy and the elemental mapping observed a core–shell structure with PtCu alloy shell and Cu–rich core (38.2 nm) as confirmed by XRD results (Fig. 5f). The formation mechanism of the core–shell structure indicated that co–reduction processes governed other than the galvanic reactions. Hence, this conclusion is in agreement with He’s study [145]. The Cu@CuPt displayed higher SA (8.6 times) toward the MOR than that of the commercial Pt/C (Table 1, #13) with a 0.5 M H2SO4 solution as electrolyte. The accelerated CV test showed that there is a 19% MA drop of Cu@CuPt and 34% MA drop of Pt/C after 1000 cycles. The characterization results proved that there is no apparent aggregation in the Cu@CuPt catalyst after 1000 cycles. But significant particle aggregation was observed for Pt/C. The authors found that larger particle size of Cu@CuPt is of benefit to the anti–aggregation ability. The loss of MA might be due to the dissolution of Cu atoms from the cores as observed from the characterization results. Core–shell PtCu alloys were also prepared by other groups and tested for ORR [146–148], MOR [96,149], EOR [32], FOR [150,151], glycol oxidation [152], and hydrogen evolution reaction [153]. The high utilization efficiency of Pt and the anti–aggregation properties under harsh reaction conditions got benefit from the hybrid structure of Cu–rich core and Pt–rich shell. Concave octahedral PtCu nanoalloys were synthesized and reported. Stars–like PtCu nanoparticles (PtCu STNPs) with particle size around 15 nm and dispersed that uniformly on the surface of the rGO with inexpensive inorganic salt (Fig. 5g) were reported [24]. During the synthesis, high–index facets were formed by the galvanic replacement to stabilize the low–coordination sites. PtCu STNPs/rGO exhibited enhanced electrocatalytic activity compared to Pt/rGO towards the MOR due to the synergetic effect of Pt and Cu components and the special architecture with better electrical transport properties (Table 1, #14). Guo et al. prepared concave cub–octahedral PtCu nanoalloys (PtCu CCO) encircled by high–index facets with an average diameter of 19 nm via co–reduction approach (Fig. 5h) [154]. The formation of concave cub–octahedral structures was ascribing to the selective surface binding of OAm. OAm formed a stable complex with Pt4+ ions to retard the rate of Pt reduction. OA acted as a stabilizer and dispersive agent in this process. OAm and OA capped on the (100) and (111) surfaces selectively and guided the metal growth on the edge or corner of the octohedras to form concave nanostructure. The PtCu CCO displayed higher activity and stability for MOR than the spherical PtCu nanoparticles (Table 1, #15). The high–index facets, the electronic structure and the inert chemical nature of Cu are the main reason of the better performance. Core–shell PtAgCu concave octahedras, with high–index facets were prepared via a hydrothermal reduction approach (Table 1, #16) [41]. The formation process followed the reduction, growth, and oxidative etching of Ag+ and Cu2+ on the Pt core. The PtAgCu@PtCu have a star–like structure with six pods and an average size of 40 nm (Fig. 5i). This alloy displayed higher activity and longer durability for the FOR owning to the unique concave structure and the bi–functional mechanism. A modified solid–state chemistry method was reported to prepare octahedral Pt2CuNi alloy nanoparticle using H2 as reducing agent and CO as shape directing agent [63]. The presence of Cu can improve the uniformity of the Pt2Ni alloy effectively by diminishing elemental segregation between Ni and Pt. The Pt2CuNi exhibits better performance towards ORR than the PtNi alloy (Table 1, #17) which is attributed to the atomic level uniformity of the particle composition. The existence of Ni and Cu suppress the competitive –OH species adsorption on the surface. Besides, the incorporation of Cu on the (111) surface can decrease surface coverage of adsorbed –OH species. Alloyed PtCuNi octahedral nanoframes (PtCuNi AONFs) with spiny nanothorns on the octahedral structure was prepared via hydrothermal method (Fig. 5j) [155]. The diffusion of Cu atoms was accelerated by the addition of Ni2+ ion in the replacement reaction between Pt4+ and the Cu neucli. Without the addition of Ni2+, concave octahedrons formed rather than hollow structure. At higher temperature, hollow structure formed due to the faster diffusion even with adding any Ni2+. The PtCu AONFs catalyst was supported on porous carbon to increase the conductivity and specific surface area. The RDE was polished with Al2O3 and sonicated in HNO3 solution before coating with catalyst. Nafion in ethanol solution was then applied to modify the surface of the catalyst–decorated electrode. The SA of as–prepared PtCu AONFs is 2.6 times of that of commercial Pt/C toward ORR in O2–saturated 0.1 M HClO4 solutions with 10 mV/s scan speed (Table 1, #18). The ADT showed that the half–wave potential was 65 mV higher than Pt/C after 8000 cycles. The main factors contributing to the better performance are the high available surface area and more active sites of the hollow nanoframe structure, as well as the decreasing adsorption energy between Pt and O due to alloy structures. Concave PtCu2 octopod nanoframes (Table 1, #19, Fig. 5k, PtCu2 CONFs) and ultrathin PtCu octopod nanoframes (Table 1, #20, Fig. 5l, PtCu UONFs) by a facile solvothermal reaction with the assistance of stirring [156]. Using Pt(acac)2 and Cu(acac)2 as precursors instead of H2PtCl6·6H2O and Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, PtCu2 CONFs were obtained instead of PtCu UONFs. The XPS results demonstrate that the PtCu2 CONFs are enclosed by high–index facets, e.g. (331), (221), and (553), which served as highly active site [157]. The PtCu UONFs has a Cu–rich core and a Pt–rich surface. To improve the ratio of Cu/Pt can further weaken the binding of intermediates to the surface Pt atoms and hasten the electrocatalytic oxidation reactions [158]. The catalyst was mixed with ethanol and coated on the Al2O3 polished glassy carbon electrode. Nafion in ethanol (0.05 wt%) was then loaded on the electrode. The MOR test was carried out in N2–saturated 0.5 M H2SO4 and 1 M CH3OH solution with a scan rate of 50 mV/s. For MOR, the PtCu2 CONFs exhibited a SA which is 7 times higher than that of the commercial Pt/C (Table 1, #19). Furthermore, it was found that the peak current density of PtCu2 CONFs is around 20 times higher than the Pt/C during the 2000 cycles durability test. However, some ultrathin edges broke after the durability test due to the dissolution of Cu atoms from the framework. PtCu2 CONFs can preserve stepped surface, architectures, and catalytic activities under harsh operating conditions. However, the structure of PtCu UONFs collapse due to the ultrathin edges. The superior activity of PtCu2 CONFs is due to the highly open nanostructures, the multiple high index facets, the enhancing mass transport, and the synergistic effect of Pt and Cu. By regulating the near surface alloys composition and tuning the synthesis time, hollow octahedral PtCu were prepared by modifying the octahedral PtCu seed with Kirkendall reaction [159]. Pa(acac)2 in DMF solution and the PtCu seed solution were mixed and treated in an autoclave. On the outer surface, The Cu atoms were etched and the Pt2+ ions were reduced to Pt atoms. Cu atoms migrated towards the outer surface and generated hollow structure. TEM and HRTEM images displayed an average size of 23.6 nm, wall thickness of 2.1 nm, and eight (111) surfaces (Fig. 5m). The obtained as–prepared hollow PtCu octahedrons supported on carbon black was tested in 0.1 M KOH solution with a RDE and showed a 30.5– and 10.3– times higher SA for ORR and MOR, respectively, due to the alloying effect of PtCu on the surface and the hollow core–shell octahedral structure (Table 1, #20). Furthermore, hollow PtCu octahedron has superior ability to activate H2O, weaker binding energy of *OH intermediates, and lower charge transfer resistance to commercial Pt/C [159]. The mechanism study showed that the ORR process over hollow PtCu octahedrons was proceed via a 4–electron pathway. This catalyst exhibited better durability with unchanged morphologies after 10,000 cycles with higher anti–CO–poisoning ability in alkaline electrolyte. Zitoun et al. reported a method to tune the size (8–18 nm) of PtCu nano–octahedra with Pt rich surface and strained (111) facets by varying the ratio of surfactant CTAB [160]. STEM and EDX elemental mapping (Fig. 5n) showed Pt–rich surface and edges and a Cu core of the PtCu nano–octahedra (18 nm) sample, which lead to a significant compressive strain on the Pt surface atoms [160]. As the CTAB increases from 0 to 20 mg, the size of crystal increased from 10 to 18 nm. The PtCu/C was mixed in water, ethanol, and Nafion (2:8:0.01), dispersed on the glassy carbon RDE, and tested in O2–saturated 0.1 M HClO4 solution. PtCu nano–octahedral (18 nm) on CB showed a 6.9– and 24.8–times higher SA than the commercial Pt/C for ORR and MOR respectively (Table 1, #21). They observed that the activity toward ORR and MOR, as well as the anti–CO–poisoning ability increased as the particle size increased, ascribing to the larger catalytic surface and faster reaction kinetics. However, it was observed that the overpotential is lower for the catalyst with smaller size due to weaker strain [160]. Pd–Cu@Pt core–shell nanocrystals were prepared by the lattice mismatch induced growth of Pt shell on the cubic PdCu alloy core [115]. PdCu seed was synthesized by immersing the Pd cubic seeds in the solution of OAm and Cu precursor to diffuse the Cu atoms into Pd cubes. There is a 0.77% mismatch between Pt and Pd, but there is 4.53% lattice mismatch between Pt shell and Pd50Cu50 core, which lead to the generation of lattice strains and variation of Pt shell growth mechanism. If Pd nanocube was selected as the seed, Pd@Pt core–shell nanocrystals formed rather than Pd–Cu@Pt nanocrystals. As the content of Pd:Cu ratio increased from 50:50 to 25:75, the lattice mismatch increased from 4.53% to 5.66% accordingly. Due to the excessive lattice mismatch, Pt islands showed on the external surface of the nanocrystals. TEM images indicated that the core–shell nanocrystals have well–defined octahedral structure (23 nm, Fig. 5o) with steps/kinks on the outer surface. To prepare the electrode, Pd–Cu@Pt/C was first dispersed in acetic acid, heated at 60 °C, and washed with ethanol. The powder obtained was mixed in the solution of DI water, IPA, and 5 wt% Nafion. This mixture was pained on a glassy carbon RDE and tested in N2–saturated 0.1 M HClO4 electrolyte in a continuous O2 flow. The as prepared catalyst exhibited a boost SA of 32 times higher than the commercial Pt/C catalyst for ORR (Table 1, #22). The stability test displayed unchanged surface structure after the durability test. The lattice mismatch led to the formation of special core–shell Pd–Cu@Pt with highly active steps/kinks, proper oxygen adsorption energy and vacancy formation energy on the surface. High–density kinks and steps over the catalyst is one of the most important factors for the higher performance. 6 Rhombic dodecahedral structure Nanoframe has highly open 3D hollow frameworks with a large accessible surface area and active sites. This specific structure promotes the electron transfer reactions [161–163]. The good performance of nanoframes benefits from the high fraction of surface–active sites, passage of reactants to the interiors of the nanocages, and high collision frequency of reactants inside the pores [163,164]. Kuo et al. deposited a 2 nm thick Pt shell on a Cu nanocubes to form a rhombic dodecahedral core and then removed the Cu core to form an ultrathin octahedral nanocages [164]. The drastic facet transformation was due to the etching by nitric acid leading to ultrathin porous nanocages. The spiny octahedral nanocages was supported on CB in the IPA. This ink was dispersed on glassy carbon RDE and dried at room temperature, following by coating with 0.1 wt% Nafion in IPA. This catalyst displayed a 3–fold improved SA towards ORR than the commercial Pt/C in the presence of Ar–purged 0.1 M HClO4 solution. Even though a good activity, a severe activity decay was observed during the ADT due to the dissolution of Cu atoms and the collapse of the ultrathin frame structure. PtCu rhombic dodecahedron nanoframes with fcc structure and the average edge length about 14.9 nm was synthesized by Li’s group by a one–pot fabrication approach [99]. As the amount of CTAC and reaction temperature increase, the particle’s structure emerged from solid spheres to nanoframes. When CTAC was replaced by CTAB as capping agent, less stable hollow nanoparticles were obtained. The long alkyl chain (CTA+) of CTAC can attach to the high–index facets and improve the dispersion of nanoparticles efficiently. Furthermore, the Cl−/O2 absorbing on (110) facets acted as oxidants to build hollow framework [139]. The SA for hollow PtCu catalyst is 1.6 times of PtB (Table 1, #23). PtCu nanoframe displayed higher anti–poisoning ability than the PtB. There is 7.1 % current drop for the PtCu nanoframe and 46.5% for the PtB after 1000 cycles, indicating a better stability of PtCu nanoframe. A one–pot solvothermal method was described in another work to prepare uniform PtCu rhombic dodecahedron nanoframes (PtCu RDNFs) with diglycolamine (DGA) and CTAC as the structure director and reductant [165]. DGA has an amino group, which can form complexes with the metal precursors to change the crystal growth kinetics. TEM images displayed frame–like structures with an average size of 32.9 nm and side length of 17.1 nm (Fig. 6 a). Rational control of reaction temperature (160–200 °C) is desired to obtain the RDNF shapes. PtCu RDNFs has higher active surface area (36.9 m2/g) than the commercial Pt/C (15.9 m2/g Pt). The activity of this catalyst for ORR was examined in O2–saturated 0.1 M HClO4 with a 1600 rpm rotating speed. The SA of PtCu RDNFs is about seven–times more active than Pt/C (Table 1, #24). The kinetics study reveals the electron transfer number (n) value of 4.03 based on the Koutecky–Levich (K–L) plots, indicating a 4–electron reduction process that protons reacted with the adsorbed oxygen to form water directly. The firm structures enable the PtCu RDNFs to have higher tolerance to aggregation and dissolution. Furthermore, the incorporated Cu atoms can reduce the dissolution of the Pt species. Furthermore, high density of atomic steps facilitated the catalytic activity. Chen’s group prepared rhombic–like hollow nanocages (Pt35Cu65 HNCs) by solvothermal method with CTAC and uric acid as reductant and structure directing agent [166]. HRTEM images display monodispersed frame–like structures (29.7 nm, Fig. 6b). If the concentration of uric acid is low, only partial hollow rhombic dodecahedral was obtained. When the feeding Pt/Cu ratio changed from 1/3 to 3/1, the particle structure evolved from rhombic–like solid nanoparticle to nanocages in a systematic way. Furthermore, the hollow nanocage structure was formed when the reaction temperature was 160–200 °C. The formation mechanism of Pt35Cu65 HNCs was shown in Fig. 7 a. With the presence of CTAC, Cu2+ will be reduced preferentially, leading to the formation Cu nanocrystals. Sufficient CTAC molecules would provide abundant CTA+ and Cl− on the (110) crystal facets, weaken the binding between OAm and Pt(acac)2, and promote the progressive anisotropic growth. Eventually, etching the crystal facets occurred through the galvanic replacement and co–deposition between Cu and Pt species. The Pt35Cu65 HNCs showed abundant active sites, easy transfer of electrons, and the downshift of the d–band electron density (Table 1, #25). Kuo’s group synthesized alloyed PtCu rhombic dodecahedral nanoframes (PtCu RDNFs) through incorporating Pt ions on the Cu template to induce the overgrowth in the (100) direction (Fig. 6c) [167]. The PtCu RDNFs formed by co–reduction and co–deposition of Cu and Pt atoms in the form of CuPt nanoparticles. Spiny PtCu RDNFs was synthesized with larger amount of Pt(acac)2 and longer reaction time compared to the normal core–frame PtCu RDNFs. PtCu RDNFs was mixed with CB in the IPA solution and stirred for 1 h. The mixture was painted on a glassy carbon RDE. The electrode was then coated with 0.1 wt% Nafion and IPA solution. The spiny PtCu RDNFs showed higher SA toward the ORR in O2–saturated 0.1 M HClO4 solution, which is 1.3 and 3 times to those of the PtCu RDNFs and the Pt/C catalysts, respectively (Table 1, #26). The superior activity benefits from the abundant surface defects and the open nanoframes structure. The K–L plots indicated a first–order kinetics with an n number 3.9 for PtCu RDNFs and 4.0 for spiny PtCu RDNFs, indicating a 4–electron mechanism for the ORR process. A general approach to obtain PtCu3 nanoframes was reported in the presence of CTAC, CuCl2, and Pt precursors, e.g. H2PtCl6, K2PtCl6 and Pt(acac)2 (Table 1, #27) [168]. The galvanic replacement together with the etching by Cl−/O2 were the main steps to form the frame structure. Excessive CTAC may blanket the surfaces of the polyhedrons and hinder the galvanic replacement and etching process. When CTAC was replaced by CTAB, deformed PtCu3 nanoframes with relatively larger size were obtained. The presence of Br− caused the slower formation rate of nanocrystals comparing to Cl− [169]. As the time of the reaction increased, the PtCu polyhedra transformed into nanoframes through the etching process by O2 and Cl− or Br− ions. Trimetallic PC@PCN catalyst with the structure of PtCuNi nanoframes (Fig. 7b) and an inner–lying PtCu dendrite were synthesized. The TEM image implied that the PC@PCN has been successive synthesized with a rhombic dodecahedral morphology. The schematic illustration of formation of PC@PCN were shown in Fig. 6d. The Pt seeds facilitated the reduction of Ni and Cu. During the formation process, the Pt atoms in the PtNi phase moved faster towards the outer edges. The Cl− from CTAC may interact with Pt precursors to form [PtCl4]2− complex and hinder the Pt reduction to obtain ultrathin PtNi nanoframeworks. Trimetallic PtCuNi nanoframes showed 16 times higher SA (Table 1, #28) than that of industrialized Pt/C for ORR in O2–saturated 0.1 M HClO4 electrolyte with a scan rate of 10 mV/s [170]. The catalyst ink was a mixture consisted with 5 wt% Nafion, DI water and IPA. The lattice mismatch, synergistic effect, and surface strain between multiple components are the main factors for enhanced catalytic performance. Furthermore, the dendritic nanoframe structure have high surface area and provided more accessible active sites. The ADT showed there is 70% SA loss and a 0.009 V half–wave potential shift after 5000 cycles. The morphology has no significant changes during the durability test. Huang’s group prepared PtCuNi RDNFs by solvothermal and two–step etching methods [171]. The first step is oxidation etching to obtain PtCuNi concave rhombic dodecahedrons as a transitional product. The second step is acid etching to obtain PtCuNi RDNFs. The particle size ad morphologies varied with the reaction time as depicted in Fig. 6e–h. At the first hour, cubic Cu–rich core nanocrystals formed by UPD of Cu atoms. Up to 8 h, imperfect rhombic dodecahedra formed, of which the Pt atoms anchored onto the edges and corners. As the reaction time further increased, the PteCueNi rhombic dodecahedral nanocrystals undergo Br−/O2 etching on the (110) facets, thus concave surfaces formed. PtCuNi RDNFs shown 5.3 times SA of the commercial Pt/C catalyst towards the ORR (Table 1, #29). The high atomic utilization, the open structure, and synergistic effect are the main factors for the good electrochemical activity. Cheng et al. prepared PtCuNi nanoparticles with hollow interior and rich Pt surface by galvanic replacement reaction, acid picking and annealing treatment to leach Cu and Ni, and accumulate Pt on the outer surface [107]. The SA of the as–prepared trimetallic catalyst towards ORR was 6.9 folds of the commercial Pt/C, ascribing to the ternary alloy effect and the open structure. Ternary Co–PtCu RNC (Fig. 6i) and Co–PtCu RDNFs with the deposition of Co species on the vertices of PtCu nanoframes in the presence of ascorbic acid (AA, Fig. 7c) were prepared successfully [69]. The edge lengths of Co–PtCu RNDFs are approximate 22.2 nm (Fig. 6j). Without AA in the reaction system, core–shell structure PtCu alloy was not observed. Without CoCl2, dendritic nanoparticles were obtained. The as–prepared catalyst was mixed with DI water, 5 wt% Nafion, and IPA in an ice bath. The SA of the Co–PtCu RNDFs/C catalyst was 2 and 16.8 times higher than that of PtCu RNDFs/C and commercial Pt/C towards the ORR in an O2–saturated 0.1 M HClO4 solution with a scan rate of 20 mV/s (Table 1, #30). The presence of Co species in the catalyst decreased the binding energy of Pt–OH and the coverage of spectator OH on the surface. The adjusted electronic structures of Pt surface atoms, the highly open 3D frame structure and the altered OH binding energy of the ternary catalyst are the main reason of better performance. The ADT revealed a negative half–wave potential shift of 5 mV for Co–PtCu RNDFs/C, 17 mV for PtCu RNDFs/C, and 19 mV for Pt/C after 10,000 cycles. The loss of MA of Co–PtCu RNDFs/C is 26.9%, 53.2% for PtCu RNDFs/C and 36.6% for Pt/C. These results indicated a higher durability of Co–PtCu RNDFs/C catalyst. Ternary fct–PtCoCu/C with order structure and homogeneous distributed particle size around 5 nm displayed a 4.9 times higher SA than that of the commercial Pt/C, which is lower than the above–mentioned Co–PtCu RNDFs/C catalyst [120]. The higher surface area of the nano–dendric structure might be the main reason of a higher performance. Three–layer core–shell PtCu nanoparticles were prepared in the presence of benzyl ether (BE), OA and OAm, as the solvent, capping agent, and reductant in the synthesis process [172]. PtCu NPs have a Pt–rich core, Cu–rich secondary layer, and Pt rich shell with an average diameter of 6.6 nm (Fig. 6k). Pt2+ interacted to BE, reduced to be Pt0 and gathered on the particle surface during the growth process. The SA of three–layer PtCu NPs/C is 3.1 times higher than that of the commercial Pt/C catalyst towards the ORR due to the improved utilization of Pt atoms by BE–induced surface segregation of Pt (Table 1, #31). Furthermore, the synergistic effect between Cu and Pt produced a higher conductivity of electrons. Zhu et al. synthesized PtCu nanoparticles with porous shell and hollow core successfully [173]. It was noticed that the nonperfect nanoframes formed and transferred to nanocages within 2 mins. Up to 10 min, Pt and Cu go through the porous shell and deposited in the cavity. The final core–shell structure catalysts with a full filling of the hollow core were obtained at 120 mins. Feng’s group prepared 3D PtCu nanocages with open structures and large surface area accessible for reactants by solvothermal method with arginine and CTAC as structure–directing and stabilizing agents (Fig. 7d) [174]. STEM images showed that hollow and polyporous cage–like PtCy nanocrystalls have an average diameter of 11.2 nm (Fig. 6l). Arginine played an important role in this process. If the amount of arginine is not within the range of 30 to 80 mM, irregular nanocrystals with severe aggregation were obtained. The as–prepared catalyst was added in ethanol under ultrasonication. This mixture was dropped on a glassy carbon electrode. Then 0.05 wt% Nafion was dropped on the dry electrode. The PtCu nanocages showed higher SA, which is 7.3 times (Table 1, #32) higher than that of Pt/C for ORR in O2–saturated 0.5 M KOH at the scan rate of 10 mV/s. The unique cage–like hollow structure with abundant defects and high–index facets, as well as the synergistic effects between the Pt and Cu are the main reason of enhanced performance. The ADT showed there is 15.4% loss of MA for PtCu NCs, which is far less than 69% of Pt/C after 1000 cycles. 7 Dendritic nanostructure Dendritic PtCu alloy with interconnected branches assembled on Cu core and resulted in a core–shell structure catalyst (Fig. 8 a–d) [175]. Core–shell Cu@PtCu(Gly), rectangular PtCu(AA), octahedral PtCu(HHA) and spherical PtCu(SBH) alloy nanocrystals were obtained using Gly, AA, hydrazine hydrate (HHA), and sodium borohydride (SBH) as reductant, respectively. It is observed that the Cu@PtCu(Gly) with a Pt/Cu ratio of 3/2 showed the best activity and stability toward MOR in a 0.5 M N2–saturated H2SO4 solution containing 1 M CH3OH at a scan rate of 50 mV/s. Its SA is 5 times higher than that of Pt/C catalyst (Table 1, #33). The synergistic effect of Pt and Cu, as well as the unique core–shell structure promoted the electron transfer from Cu to Pt. The Cu cores can prevent Pt from agglomerating and leaching in acidic medium. Cu species can decrease the binding energy of the adsorbed poisoning species. Fu et al. prepared dendritic PtCu bimetallic nano–assemblies (DBNAs, Fig. 8e–g) in the presence of PVP and arginine to promote self–assembly [176]. The interactions between arginine–metal ions played a key role in expediting the self–assembly of unit nanocrystals. By varying the Pt/Cu ratio, the phase composition, and the structure of the nano–assemblies can be changed. The dendritic Pt1Cu3 nano–assemblies contained both PtCu alloy and the pure Cu phase in the presence of excess Cu2+ with respect to PtCl4 2−. Pt3Cu1 displayed a SA about 2.4 times higher than that of PtB for MOR due to large porosity (Table 1, #34). A Cu seed–mediated approach for preparing CuPtRu alloy with dendritic core–frame rhombic dodecahedra (CuPtRu DCFRD, Fig. 8h) and frame rhombic dodecahedra nanostructure (CuPtRu DFRD, Fig. 8i) were synthesized using DDA as the capping ligand and reductant [177]. The Pt and Ru on the vertices and edges of the Cu seeds were removed by etching, to obtain dendritic core–frame nanostructures. HAADF–STEM images and EDX element mapping clearly shown the core–frame structure, which can protect Ru from leaching. The TEM images of the samples demonstrate the structure of PtCuCo alloy with a dendritic shell and a hollow cavity, which has an average size about 45 nm. The PtCuCo nanomaterials displayed higher activity for ethylene glycol electrooxidation than the Pt/C catalyst. In this process, both H+ and Cl− are essential to the formation of branched structure. The SA of the as–prepared PtCu HBNDs is 1.7 times to that of the commercial PtRu/C catalysts due to pen porous structure (Table 1, #35). There are numerous other works reporting dendritic structures for various oxidation reactions, e.g. MOR [180–184], ORR [185], glucose detection [186,187], ethylene glycol oxidation [37,39], H2O2 detection [188], hydrogen evolution [71]. The enhanced performance is attributed to the electronic synergistic effect in dendrite structures. Highly branched PtCu alloy nanodendrites were synthesized a facile approach [97]. By tuning the molar ratio of the metals, Pt3Cu1, Pt1Cu1 and Pt1Cu3 nanodendrites were obtained. The TEM image indicated a uniform dispersion of Pt1Cu1 nanodendrites with branched structure (100 nm, Fig. 8k). The high index facets of the dendritic structure led to shifted binding energy of PtCu nanodendrites with improved the MOR activity. The Pt1Cu1 nanodendrites exert highest activity than Pt3Cu1 and Pt1Cu3 nanodendrites. Pt1Cu1 catalyst was mixed with ethanol and Nafion was added afterward. This mixture was coated on a glassy carbon electrode and dried at room temperature. The activity of Pt1Cu1 was tested in a N2–saturated 0.5 M H2SO4 and 0.5 M CH3OH for MOR. The SA of Pt1Cu1 is more than 4 times increase compared to the commercial Pt/C catalyst toward the MOR (Table 1, #36). The high index facets and dendritic alloy structure mainly contribute to better performance. The ADT showed that Pt1Cu1 loss 5.2% activity, which is less than the 13.9% of Pt/C after 1000 cycles without significant change of the size and dendritic structure. Dendritic PtCu nanoparticles were synthesized by a facile one–step method using Brij58 as surfactant at room temperature (Fig. 8l) [189]. By introducing bromide ions, tripod–like structures were obtained. Due to the strong coordination between Br− and Pt4+, Br− can accelerate the formation of complexes (PtBr6)2−, decrease the reaction rate and increase the dispersity. Comparing to the dendritic PtCu and commercial PtB, these tripod–like PtCu nanostructures exhibited higher electrocatalytic activity (2 times) and CO tolerance for catalyzing MOR (Table 1, #37). 8 Nanowire structure Porous networks for nanowires enable exposure of more accessible surface area and facilitate mass transport [72,73,190]. Self–supported and intertwined structures would diminish the interfacial electronic resistance significantly. Furthermore, the rough and ultrathin nanowire with plentiful corner/edge can raise the utilization efficiency of surface Pt atoms [119]. Ternary PtCuPd based catalysts were widely studied and applied for ORR and MOR reactions with good performance [113–119]. Irregularly ultrathin curved PtPdCu nanowires with diameter within 5–8 nm, as shown in the TEM images (Fig. 9 a), was prepared by solvothermal method in the presence of PVP and KBr [191]. PVP and Br− directed the anisotropic growth were observed by adsorption on different crystal facets of PtPdCu as catalyzed by the formation of (PdBr4)2− and (CuBr4)2−. The MA of the PtPdCu nanowires is 2–fold of commercial Pt/C catalysts (Table 1, #38) for MOR. The synergetic effects of the Pt, Pd and Cu atoms, inducing CO oxidation by the formation of Pd–OH contribute to good performances. Zhang’s group prepared PtPdCu nanoalloy in the presence of NaBH4 and washed with HNO3 solution to obtain PtPdCu nanowires [119]. The as prepared PtPdCu NWs displayed 5.7–fold larger SA than Pt/C for ORR due to the modified electronic structure, higher mass transfer of reactants and products in the interconnected structure, and higher anti–CO–poison ability. The mechanism of the acid etching process is proposed by Li’s group [3]. They noticed that Cu atoms migrate to the acid solution, while Pd atoms migrated to the inner part of the particle. Then, Pt atoms migrate to the outer surface and gather to form crystalline structure. At the same time, vacancies formed and further promote the migration of Cu to the acid solution. However, as the number of vacancies decreased, the promotional effect disappeared. A decrease of 23 mV half–wave potential for Pt1Cu1Co1Ni1 NPQA was observed, which is lower than 33 mV for the commercial Pt/C. The synergistic electronic interaction between Pt, Cu and N atoms can effectively improve the electronic transfer and catalytic activity. Furthermore, the Cu vacancy defects facilitated the adsorption of HO* intermediate and the desorption of O* intermediate to the Pt atoms as calculated by DFT study. The plausible reaction mechanism and the configuration of reaction intermediates for ORR in acid media are shown in Fig. 10b,c. The Cu vacancy and defects can significantly improve the ORR activity. Generally, vacancy defects generated new synergetic coordination of active metal species and presented unique electronic properties [200]. During the formation of defects, lattice compressive strain of Pt was detected, which reduced the formation energy of vacancy [199]. Defects can bind some reaction intermediates during the reaction process and thus improved the catalytic performance. The defects were formed by chemical etching of Cu atoms and leaching of OH groups from the perfect PtCu crystals in this case. The rugged and smooth PtCu nanowire displayed 9.2– and 4.7– fold SA higher than that of the commercial Pt/C (Table 1, #45). DFT calculation indicated the higher performance of rugged structure nanowire is ascribing to the higher Cu content and the existence of (111) and (511) surface with higher water dissociation and carboxyl dehydrogenation. 9 Nanosphere structure Shen et al. prepared monodisperse PtCu nanosphere (4.8 nm) with a Pt–rich skin via hydrothermal method (Fig. 12 a) using CTAB and OAm as the surfactant and DMF as the reducing agent [62]. OAm can provide a long–chain capping on the particles. Besides, the van der Waals force facilitates self–assemble of PtCu NPs into a hexagonal array. The activity of the PtCu NPs is 6–fold higher than that of the Pt/C catalyst for MOR in the solution of N2–purged 1 M CH3OH and 0.5 M H2SO4.The durability test showed that the activity dropped 20.7% for PtCu NPs after 1000 cycles, which is less than 35.4% for Pt/C catalyst, indicating a better stability of PtCu NPs. Truncated octahedral Pt4Cu crystals formed sub–micron porous tubes (Pt4Cu–SMPBs, 5 nm) and showed high activity for ORR [141]. The MA of the Pt4Cu–SMPBs displayed 5 times higher activity than commercial Pt/C catalyst for ORR application (Table 1, #46). The stability was proved much higher than Pt/C according to the comparison of half–wave potential and MA drop after 8000 cycles. In another study, mesoporous PtCu Alloy nanoparticles were synthesized using a simple method with diblock copolymer micelle PEO–b–PMMA (poly (ethylene oxide)–b–poly (methyl methacrylate)) as soft sacrificial templates (Fig. 12b) [21]. AA can reduce Pt and Cu precursors and drive the alloy nucleation around PEO–b–PMMA templates. XPS results indicated that both Pt0 and Cu0 are present on the surface without significant phase segregation. The SA of Pt84Cu16 is 3 times of PtB towards MOR (Table 1, #47). Liu’s group prepared PtCu bimetallic alloy nanocrystal clusters by a polyelectrolyte–promoted process using poly (diallyldimethylammonium) chloride (PDDA) as the stabilizer and soft reductant [80]. PDDA has modest reducibility, as well as good hydrophilicity and stability. SEM results showed a uniform spherical structure with a diameter approximately 107 nm (Fig. 12c). The HR–SEM image indicated that nanospheres are assembled by nanograins (Fig. 12d). The SA of MOR on PtCu nanocrystal clusters is 2–fold higher of commercial Pt/C (Table 1, #48). The primary nanograins with abundant active sites and the synergistic effects between Cu and Pt atoms contributed to the synergistic activity. The trimetallic Pt34Pd33Cu33 nanocrystals (35–52 nm) with defects and cavities were consisted of many small grains (<5 nm, Fig. 12e) and synthesized using CTAC, AA and citric acid as surfactants and reductants in aqueous–phase [204]. In the absence of citric acid or AA, irregular particles or aggregated grains were formed (Table 1, #49). When amphiphilic dioctadecyldimethylammonium chloride and nitrogen modified graphene were used as surfactant and support respectively during the synthesis, multimetallic mesoporous hemispheres PtPdCu catalyst was obtained, which displayed a 3.8–fold higher SA toward MOR than the commercial Pt/C in N2–saturated 0.1 M HClO4 and 1 M CH3OH solution at a scan rate of 50 mV/s [113]. During accelerating durability test, there is a 23% decrease of the peak current density for the PtPdCu/C, which a lower than 47% for Pt/C after 1500 cycles. The incorporation of Rh improved the stability significantly. The improved anti–CO–poisoning ability and faster electron and mass transfer are the main reasons for improved performance. The dendritic structure proved larger surface area with more active sites. The incorporation of Rh elements can induce a compressive train in the lattice and thus increase the activity. Furthermore, oxophilic properties of Rh and Cu can promote the formation of OH species to enhance CO tolerance ability. Yuan et al. synthesized trimetallic NiPtCu nanoalloy with porous structures. The trimetallic Pt60Ni3Cu37 nanoalloys consist of large numbers of nanopores less than 5 nm (Fig. 12f) [81]. XRD results indicated the trimetallic Pt60Ni3Cu37 nanocatalysts were alloy structures (Table 1, #50). Spherical hollow PtCu NPs was synthesized and encapsulated into a carbon shell by mild annealing in order to prevent Pt and Cu dissolution and thus improve the activity and stability [205]. The as prepared S–H–PtCu@C showed a 1.9 times higher SA than the Pt/C catalyst for MOR. The SA of PtRuCu/C catalyst is 8.2 times higher than that of Pt/C for MOR. The mechanism study showed that Ru(OH)ads/Cu(OH)ads can improve the oxidation of CO and thus reduce the CO poisoning of Pt active sites. Furthermore, the mechanism for MOR has been studied over PtCuFe catalyst as shown in Fig. 12g [4]. At the first step, C–H bond broke and formed H2COHad, which will further be converted to formaldehyde. The adsorbed H2COH undergo dehydrogenation and generated HC = Oad. At low potentials (below 0.7 V), the HC = Oad was converted to HCOOH or HCOOCH3, following the direct pathway. If the potential is high, the adsorbed CO can be removed, the HCOOHsurf was converted to CO2 following the indirect pathway. They found that the reaction pathway depended on the nature of the electrode surface. 10 Conclusions and outlooks The synthesis, characterization, formation mechanism and electrocatalytic performance of PtCu–based polymetallic alloy with different structures have been systematically reviewed and critically discussed. PtCu–based alloys have received wide attention in electrocatalysis due to their superior electrocatalytic performance towards ORR and MOR compared to the commercial Pt/C (Fig. 1, Table 1). During the past one year, more and more multi–metallic PtCu–based catalysts were found high active for ORR and MOR, e.g. PtCuPd (ORR: 32 times of Pt/C) [115], PtCuPd (MOR: 19.4 times of Pt/C) [117], PtCuNi (ORR: 16 times of Pt/C) [170], and PtCuCo (ORR: 16.8 times of Pt/C) [69]. Bimetallic hollow PtCu octahedron (ORR: 30.5 times of Pt/C) [159], PtCu nano–octahedra (MOR: 24.8 times of Pt/C) [160], and PtCu Nanowires network (MOR: 19.4 times of Pt/C) [199] were reported with good activity and stability toward ORR and MOR. The enhanced catalytic performance of above–mentioned catalysts was mainly attributed to the following factors: (1) The synergetic effects upon modified surface electronic properties of Pt and the d–band shift of alloys caused by lattice mismatch could change the chemisorption energies of reactants, products, and intermediates; The lattice mismatch between different metals may cause the generation of special core–shell structures (highly active steps/kinks, surface vacancy and defects) with proper oxygen adsorption energy and vacancy formation energy on the surface. (2) The incorporation of Cu can enhance the dispersity of Pt atoms on the surface due to the geometric effect. By varying the preparation method, the intrinsic characteristics of the PtCu based alloys can be obtained, e.g., open porous structures, Pt rich surface, large surface area, high anti–CO–poisoning ability. The reductant, stabilizer, and the solvent are important factors that affect the nucleation and growth rates of nanocrystalls. (3) PtCu alloy generated more oxygenated species at lower potentials, thus diminish the poisoning of the surface and improve the stability. (4) Pt and other metals modified the surface electronic structure, thus changing the chemisorption of reactants, products, and the intermediates. The vacancy defects play an essential role in improving the catalytic performances. However, some challenges remained and more efforts are needed to explore the effect of defects. (a) It is still difficult to control the structure of defects precisely to minimize the side reactions. (b) It is desired to track the evolution of defects to improve the stability and to guide catalyst design. (c) Currently, the characterization techniques are still inadequate for more accurate measurements of the role of defects. The stability and durability of the catalysts are important factors for application in industry. The stability can be closely related with following factors as summarized from the reviewed references. (a) The incorporation of other metals components can decrease the Pt–OH binding energy and thus improve the stability. (b) Catalysts with larger particle size usually have higher stability. (c) Ultrathin frameworks may collapse due to Cu dissolution in harsh medium. Hence, catalysts with polyhedral structures may have higher stability compared to the dendrites or nanoframes. (d) Catalysts with core–shell structure may have better stability since higher coverage of stable Pt shell on the outer surface can protect the catalyst from Cu dissolution. The size effect to the catalytic performance of multimetallic catalysts is truly complicated, since different catalysts with various structures were synthesized by different methods and reagents. It is difficult to obtain a conclusion quantitatively. However, according to the correlation of particle size and SA of various catalysts (Fig. 13 ), we can find some clue that particles with size less than 7 nm are more likely to display high catalytic activity for ORR and less than 38 nm for MOR. It is easier to understand that methanol has larger size than oxygen, thus larger particle with larger pores is favorable for MOR. Currently, methods for the synthesis of polymetallic PtCu based alloys with different structure have been widely reported. However, most of them are time–consuming and hard to obtain polyporous nanocrystals with a size within 15 nm. The presence of surfactant is difficult to be removed and environmental harmful. Furthermore, the utilization efficiency of Pt is ultra–high due to the high Pt content in the catalyst. Therefore, facile synthetic strategies to prepare ultrafine nanocrystals with low Pt content and high activity are highly desired. Future work aimed at developing one–pot surfactant free process to prepare highly active and stable ultrafine nanocrystal with Pt rich surface and cheap metal–rich core. The doping of metal cation emerged as an effective way to control the morphology of nanocrystalls in nanoscience. The introduction of cost–effective metal was proved as an effective means for optimizing the activity, stability, and the economics of the new catalysts. However, the fine tuning of the nanostructure, metal dispersion, particle size, surface vacancy and defects, functional groups are still highly desired to be studied systematically to build a facile method to precisely synthesize multi–metallic catalyst with excellent activity and stability. Except for the noble Pt–based multi–metallic catalyst, non–precious metal, e.g., Co, Ni, Fe, Ce–based catalysts should be widely studied to replace Pt–based catalyst. However, the catalysts reported in the literature, only showed comparable activity as the commercial Pt/C. Hence, it is highly desired to systematically study and improve the catalytic performance of non–noble metal–based catalysts. Dr. Wenjuan Yan obtained her Ph.D from University of Kansas, under supervision of Prof. Bala Subramaniam. Her research interests include epoxidation of olefins, selective oxidation of biomass to carboxylic acids and synthesis of mesoporous catalysts for liquid phase reactions. Prof. Xin Jin joined China University of Petroleum and received early promotion to associate professor. His research area is on nanocatalysis. He is the recipient of ACS Catalysis Early Career Award, Kokes Award and Frank Bowdish Award.

coredata.dc:description: Proton exchange membrane fuel cell and direct methanol fuel cells have gained more attention due to high–energy density, remarkable conversion efficiency, and low emission. However, their widely practical application was hindered by the high usage, limited sources, and high price of Pt catalysts. To achieve more cost–effective catalytic systems, PtCu–based multi–metallic nanoparticles are highly efficient for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and methanol oxidation reaction (MOR). The incorporation of non–noble Cu metal can alter the properties of hybrids by forming new facets, planes, edges to promote the cleavage or formation of chemical bonds in catalytic reaction. This is a rapid growing area with numerous contributions from the interdisciplinary areas of nanocatalysis. This paper has summarized the recent progress in the past two years, in synthesizing PtCu–based alloys with various composition and morphologies, and critically discussed the effect of the catalyst preparation method, metal precursor, surfactant, reductant and heating temperature on nanostructure and electronic configuration. The important role of the composition, size, and morphology of PtCu bimetallic catalysts for electro oxidation reactions has been further established for structure–dependency studies. The challenges and perspectives of nanocatalysts for ORR and MOR discussed in this work is to provide further insights into rational design for cost–effective materials for energy.
